item.title: Introduction
item.description: Hello, World! Hey there! I am Eben Quenneville, a Physics student at the University of New Hampshire. This is a publicly accessible sub-section of my personal notes network built using Obsidian.

item.title: Soldering
item.description: Soldering Soldering is the process of connecting a component to a PCB by melting solder between the surfaces. Traditionally, soldering is done using a soldering iron - essentially a very hot stick of metal that you gently touch to heat the circuit board, solder, and component together.

item.title: Ergonomic Keyboards
item.description: Ergonomic Keyboards An ergonomic keyboard is a tool for inputting symbols to a computer in a way that doesn’t compromise on the user’s comfort. Typical features that might make a keyboard more ergonomic that the traditional counterpart are a split design, ortholinear or columnar staggered keys, or non-traditional angles.

item.title: Quantum Mechanics
item.description: Quantum Mechanics Quantum Mechanics The study of the behavior of nature at a scale below the atom. References Modern Physics: Chapter 4.

item.title: Planck Constant
item.description: Planck’s Constant Planck’s constant, denoted by h, is a fundamental physical constant. A photon has energy equal to its Frequency multiplied by h. In SI Units, it has the exact value h = 6.62607015 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J}\cdot \text{Hz}^{-1}.

item.title: Photons
item.description: Photons Photons are a fundamental particle, like Electrons. They are bundles, or quanta, of light. In certain experiments, it is observed that light behaves exactly like a wave.

item.title: Snells Law
item.description: Snell’s Law Snell’s Law allows use to predict the path of light as it travels from one medium to another. Many scientists tried to find a mathematical relationship for this, but the discovery came at the hand of Willebrord Snell, a Duth mathematician.

item.title: Index of Refraction
item.description: Index of Refraction A medium is a material through which light or some other wave passes. Different transparent mediums have different optical densities, based on the speed of light in the material.

item.title: Weight
item.description: Topic: Weight The weight of an object is defined in two ways: The mass of the object times the force of gravity: W = mg The value measured on a scale The issue with the second definition ...

item.title: Velocity
item.description: Velocity Velocity is a vector that denotes how fast and in what direction something is moving. Mathematically, it is written as \vec{v} = \vec{x}/t where \vec{x} represents the displacement.
